Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: MANCHURIA. RUSSIANS OCCUPY SHAHOT-SE. FORCES ADVANCING SOUTH
div.p: St.Petersburg, May 23.

General Linievich reports that a Russian force occupied Shahot-se on the 20th inst. Another compelled the Japanese to evacuate Chantu-fu station on the 17th inst., and both forces continued to advance south. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADMIRAL BIRILEFF. TO COMMAND PACIFIC FLEET.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 23.
Admiral Birileff has been appointed to the command of the Balsic Float with the right of command over the army. (Havas.)
St. Petersburg, May 23.
Admiral Birileff has been appointed to the command of the Pacific fleet with independent powers. (Reuter.)

div.head: COTTON AS CONTRABAND. GOVERNMENT ASKED TO PROTEST.
div.p: London, May 23.

Colonel Nolan has called the attention of the government to the decision with regard to the British S.S "Calchas” and asks that they should protest against the treatment of cotton as contraband of war. (Reuter.)

div.head: STRANGE BOW-STREET CASE. THE PASSPORT TO RUSSIA.
div.p: London, May 23.

The well-known journalist Brailsford and the actor McCulloch were charged at Bow street with conspiring to obtain a passport to Russia purporting to be for McCulloch but actually handed to the Russian revolutionary who was killed by the bomb explosion of the 11th of March. The Solicitor-General, in prosecuting, described this as an offence of exceeding gravity, endangering the peaceful relations between Russia and Great Britain. The case was adjourned for a fortnight. (Reuter.)

div.head: GRAND DUKE SERGIUS'S ASSASSIN HANGED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 23.
Kalajeff, the assassin of the Grand Duke Sergius has been hanged. (Havas.)

div.head: TURCO-ROUMANIAN DIFFICULTY SETTLED
div.p: Bucharest, May 23.
The Turco-Roumanian difficulty has been settled in favor of Roumania. (Reuter.)

div.head: LYONS'S STRIKE ENDED.
div.p: Lions, May 28.
The strike is at an end. (Havas.)

div.head: DEATH OF FRENCH SCULPTOR.
div.p: Paris, May 23.
The sculptor Paul Dubois is dead (Havas.)

Paul Dubois, who was one of the greatest of modern sculptures, was born at Nogent-sur-Seine, July 18, 1829. He was destined by his father for the legal profession, but his artistic tastes constrained him to devote himself to sculpture, and he went to Paris to become the pupil of the sculptor Toussaint, with whom he remained three years. In 1859 he went to Italy, and in 1860 executed at Florence the model for "St. John a Child," which was finished at Rome, exhibited at the Salon of 1863, and is now at the Luxembourg, together with “A Florentine Singer of the Fiftienth Century." This last is in silvered bronze and thought its many reproductions in smaller size has become very popular. Other works which may be cited are the tomb of General'la Moriciere, one of the masterpieces of modern statuary (1878), which is at Nantes; and busts of Bonnat, Cabanel, Paul Baudry, Gounod, Pasteur (1890), and other celebrities. M. Dubois also studied painting, and had executed nine portraits and beautiful copies of old masters but was a very irregular contributor to the Salon exhibitions. In 1873 he was appointed keeper of the Luxembourg Museum, and director of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, May 30, 1878. Elected a member of the Academie des Beaux-Arts in 1876, he was one of the Jury of Admission for the selection of sculpture at the Exposition of 1878. He was a grand officer of the Legion of Honour (1889).

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: London, May 23.
M.C.C; beat Kent by 9 wickets. (Reuter.)

div.head: HOUSE OF COMMONS. MONDAY'S “SCENE.”. MATTER NOW DROPPED.
div.p: London, May 23.

The scene in the House of Commons is without parallel in the history of the House. The speakers, chiefly Mr Lyttelton, were greeted with angry cries of "Bring in the Guards!” “Where are the police!” and by the blowing of police whistles. After Mr. Austen Chamberlain and Mr. Brodrick has sat down, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman again appealed to Mr. Balfour declaring that by his silence he alone was responsible for the disturbance. This renewed the uproar and Mr. Balfour rose and severely rebuked the House for its unseemly behaviour. Never in his experience had it refused to listen to a Minister speaking for the Government, nor had the Opposition presumed to dictate the order of speeches. To-night's precedent, if followed, would absolutely ruin the Commons. Mr.Lyttelton again rose, but the storm burst with redoubled fury. The Deputy Speaker adjourned the House by virtue of the new rule reffering to a grave disorder. The prolongation of the scene is attributed to the fact that the Deputy-Speaker, who presided in consequence of the Speaker's illness, has no power to suspend individual Members.(Reuter.)
London, May 23.

House of Commons.- The House to-day was thronged, and Sir H. Campbell Bannerman and Mr. Balfour were received with extraordinary ovations on entering. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman asked whether in view of the confusion created by the recent declarations of Ministers with reference to the fiscal question and the Colonial Conference, Mr. Balfour would fix a day for a vote of censure. Mr. Balfour said that two Ministers were prepared to clear up any confusion yesterday, when they wore prevented by the disgraceful proceedings which Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman did nothing to prevent. He had no objection to fixing a day provided he had an undertaking that the debate would be conducted with ordinary de ceney and fair play. The matter was then dropped. (Reuter.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan intends going to Bad Gastein shortly.
Prince Abbas Pasha Halim and Abani Pasha, Minister of War, came down from Cairo last night.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Seville on the 19th inst, after a long and painful illness, of Mine Marguerite Eeman-van Moutenaeken, wife of Judge Albert Eeman, president of the Mansourah Mixed Tribunal.

Sheikh Muhamed Abdou, Grand Moufti of Egypt, is leaving for Europe on the 15th proxo. His religious duties will be performed by Hassan Pasha Assem during his absence. The Grand Moufti’s health is, we regret to state, not very good, and his medical advisers have ordered him to go for a change of air.
Mgr. Cyril VIII., Greek Catholic Patriarch of Egypt, is loaving Cairo to spend the summer atBamleh.

Kaimakam Drury Bey, Controller of the Port of Suskin, is staying at the San Stefano Hotel-Casino. He is studying the Ports and Lighthouses Administration with a view to the foundation of a similar administration for the Sudan ports.
Captain G. C. M. Hall, R. E., goods manager of the State Railways, will leave for England tomorrow.
The salary of Mr. Runel A. Colvin, the newly-appointed chief engineer to the Sudan Irrigation Service, will be L.E. 428 per annum.

The marriage of Mr. Claude J. Rolo to Miss Celine Piha, the daughter of M. and Mme Elie A. Piha Bey, was celebrated at the residence of Mr. Jacques Rolo at Rue de Corinthe, Alexandria, yesterday afternoon. There was a very large and fashionable attendance of wedding guests, including all the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps at Alexandria and all the leading representatives of Alexandria society. The Khedive was represented by his Chief Equerry, Lewa. Thurneyssen Pasha. The religious ceremony was performed by the Grand Rabbi of Alexandria. The wedding party afterwards adjourned to the garden, which presented a most animated spectacle. There were two buffets, one in the garden and the other in the house. An orchestra played a charming selection of airs in the garden and the guests did not leave until 8 o'clock.

The Brindisi Mail will arrive at Alexandria this evening and will be distributed at the G P.O. at 7.10 a.m. tomorrow.

div.head: The Coptic Language
div.p: Mr W. E. Crum has started classes in the Coptic language at the London University.

div.head: Native Killed
div.p: A goods train ran over a native on the Customs quays yesterday, the man being killed on the spot.

div.head: Cyprus
div.p: The May issue of the “Cyprus Journal” is full of interesting matter affecting the commerce and industries of the island.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Saida Zenab quarter of Cairo during to night and at dawn to-morrow will be poisoned by tho police.

div.head: Egyptian Estates, Limited
div.p: The committee of the London Stock Exchange has granted a special settling day to the above company, which has been fixed for May 30.
The Sinai Expedition, which Professor Flinders Petrie undertook recently, is to be the subject of six lectures by the professor during this and next month at the London University.

div.head: Sudan Exploration
div.p: The London Stock Exchange Committee has appointed May 30 as special settlingday for "Sudan Exploration", further issue of 58,834 shares of 10s. each, fully paid, Nos, 60,001 to 118,834.

div.head: Sharaki Land
div.p: The scheme for extending the prohibition of Sharaki land irrigation in Upper and Lower Egypt has been submitted to the approbation of the Legislative Council prior to it being promulgated in the form of a Decree.

div.head: The Pilgrimage Enquiry
div.p: The enquiry into the incidents, which occurred during the pilgrimage, is continuing. The evidence of the Emir el-Hag, the commandant of the soldiers accompanying the pilgrimage, and others has been heard.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 20th and 21st inst. 25 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these, 18 were British, 1 Russian, 4 German, 2 Dutch. The receipts for the two days were frs, 609,927.51, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 6,617,704.16.

div.head: The Sais Sarcophagi
div.p: The services of M. Moret have been engaged by the Government for two months in order to edit a part of the catalogue of the sarcophagi of the Sais dynasty. He has been appointed provisionally for this special duty at a salary of L.E. 33 per month.

div.head: An Interesting Visitor
div.p: Considerable interest was recently aroused at Khartoum by the visit of Sheikh Mahomed Aly Omar Or, head of the Genilab Arabs, who live near Suakin and roam about over a large area between that port and Kassala. It was chiefly through his agency that Osma Digna was captured.

div.head: A. L M. & D. S
div.p: The concert given last night at the San Stefamo Casino by the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society was an unqualified success, a large attendance being present and the programme affording great pleasure. Abundance of matter compels us to hold over our criticism of the concrrt till to-morrow.

div.head: The Summer Exodus
div.p: Is it necessary to remind those who intend touring this summer how useful a knowledge of languages would be to them. The rapid and practical method of the Berlitz School can in a very short time give a sufficient knowledge of the language of the country in which one may be traveling. A free trial lesson will give ample proof. [Advt.]

div.head: Empire Day
div.p: An open-air concert will be held at the Kasr-el-Nil Barracks at 9.30 this evening. M. F. Watson Ramsay, bandmaster of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has arranged an exellent programme for the occasion, and a large audience is expected to be present. A holiday has been given to the pupils of the military schools throughout Egypt. At Alexandria the day will be celebrated at Mr. Alderson’s Garden in Bulkeley.

div.head: French Fete
div.p: A meeting of the members of the French colony in Cairo was held on Monday evening to elect a committee for the organization of the fete which takes place yearly on the 14th of July. The following members were elected : MM. J. Barois, B. Muller, Comte de Serionne, Paul Oziol, A. Leroux, L. Pitelle, Maitre J. B. Tramoni, Dr. Brossard, C. Battenberg, Tourneron Bey, Conin Pasteur, G. Vayssie, A. Bianchi, Paul Manse, Philippoteanx, H. Cernadou, Souter, A. Derroja, Proutelle, G. Privat.

div.head: Sailors and Soldiers' Institute
div.p: A concert will be given at the institute to-morrow evening, commencing at 8 o'clock. The programme is attractive and includes the names of Mrs. R. N. Gamble, Mrs. Gordon, Miss MunGavin, Miss M. K. Gibson, Mr. H. M. Dodwell, Mr. O.S. Heaton, Prof. Rizzitano, Gunner S. Hall, Private Russell, and Drummer Pearce. Songs, recitations, pisnoforte, violin, and mandoline solos, a performance on the bells, and an exhibition of club swinging should ensure a pleasant evening being passed. There will be no charge for admission, but a collection will be taken at the door.

div.head: ASSIOUT FREE OF LOCUSTS. NO EGGS DISCOVERED.
div.p: Assiout Moudirieh is now pronounced entirely free from locusts. A careful watch is being exercised in this and in the other provinces of Upper Egypt, but no eggs have been discovered anywhere except in one district of Minieh. The inhabitants have responded with great alacrity to the orders of the local authorities.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
div.p: The seriousness of the present situation can be grasped when we state that the actual loss due to the worm during the cotton season last year is estimated at between 1,000,000l. and 2,000,000l. at least.

The life-history of the worm is as follows : About the beginning of June the moth lays eggs (about 300) on a leaf near the bottom of the plant. These are easily soon on examination. The period of incubation is from three to four days. The young worms begin to feed on the leaf on which they are hatched. They grow very rapidly, and in a few days spread over the entire plant. After feeding (from 18 to 22 days), the worms burrow into the soil, construct cells, and pass the pupa stage (8 to 10 days). The moths then hatch out and commence laying again. The whole life-history is thus from 30 to 40 days, depending to a certain extent on climatic conditions. In July, therefore, we bare a second brood, followed by a thud in August, after which the worms find food elsewhere. It is clear that the pest can be most satisfactorily attacked by picking the leaves on which the eggs are found. When the worms have spread over the plant, they eat the young buds, flowers, leaves, &c., and it is impossible to do much. Fields have to be examined every few days when eggs are being laid. It is evident that the more thoroughly the June brood is kept in check, the less severe will subsequent generations be.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras el Tin Palace today from Montazah. Tomorrow, at about 10 a.m., a his Highiness will visit the Mosques of Abou El Abbas,Yakut El Arahi,and El Abasiri, where religious instruction is given.
The Khedive will leave to-morrow afternoon by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. "Amphitrite” for Constantinople, en route to London.
Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs, will probably accompany the Khedive on his visit to London.
"Al Lewa" says that on the occasion of the Khedive’s visit to Constantinople, his Highness will ask the Sultan to allow him to extend the Mariout railway line as far as the borders of Tripoli.

div.head: BEHERA COMPANY.
div.p: The Behera Company is evidently taking advantage of the decision of the Egyptian Government to suspend all important land sales in order to dispose of large blocks of its own land. A notice of a very important land sale by this company will be found on page 4.

div.head: "LONDON GAZETTE."
div.p: The following extracts from the "London Gazette,” dated 16 May, 1905, are of interest:

Princess Charlotte of Wales's (Royal Berkshire Regiment). — Second Lieutenant L. W. Bird to be Lieutenant, vice H. H. Shott, D.S.O., seconded for service under the Colonial Office. Dated 15 February, 1905.
Second Lieutenant L. C. Howard is removed from the Service for absence without leave. Dated 17 May, 1905.

div.head: MARIANNE HUGHES FUND.
div.p: The annual meeting of the committee of thd Marianne Hughes Fund was held at the British Agency, Cairo, on the 22nd inst, at 6.30 p.m. There were present the Earl and Countess of Cromer, Miss Lassel, matron of Kasr-el-Ainy Hospital, Dr. Wilson, Mr. Elliot, and Dr. Madden, hon. secretary and treasurer.

The hon. secretary presented the accounts for 1904, which were approved, and reported the purchase of a new carriage for the sisters of Kasr-el-Ainy, and, also, the gift of a horse from Major Blunt, Director of Supplies, E. A., to whom the warmest thanks of the committee are due. During the past season 20 nurses were enrolled on the register, which is kept by the matron of the Anglo-American Hospital, Cairo, to whom applications for private nurses should be made. In conclusion, the committee wish to thank Mr. Rowlatt for his kindness in again auditing the accounts of the fund.
The following is the statement of accounts of the Marianne Hughes Fund for 1904:—

div.head: ATTEMPTED MURDER IN MOHAMED ALY SQUARE.
div.p: This morning, at about 10.30 ’o'clock, a serious outrage took place in Mohamed Aly square, Alexandria, which resulted in grave injuries to Ahmed Khalil, late consular janissary to the American consular agency and at present bowab to St. Mark's Small Building. While the man was on an errand and was walking through the square to collect some money , an unknown person rushed up to him and folded him to the ground with a sharp instrument,. evidently some iron weapon. His upper lip was cut clean open and a gaping wound extends under the nose. The aggressor at once made off, leaving his victim lying in a pool of blood. The injured man has been taken to the Government Hospital. He is quite unable to identify his would-be assassin, who fortunately did not plunge the weapon far enough into the man's mouth to inflict fatal injuries to the throat. It is strange that such a bloodthirsty outrage could have been committed in Mohamed Aly square, which was crowded with people, at that hour, and the assassin have escaped scot free.

div.head: NYAM-NYAM EXPEDITION.
div.p: It appears that Yambio, the Nyam-Nyam chief, whose death we announced in our Saturday’s issue, had been the mainstay of the whole revolt, and that from the first his people wanted to come in, but were kept back by him. He ruled his people with extreme severity, his only punishment was death, and this was meted out frequently for the slightest offence. Large numbers of women and girls were found closely confined and jealously guarded in his village. All were released and sent book to their villages whenever possible. Among the trophies captured was the Sultan's great war drum. It stands four feet high, is cut out of a single tree trunk, and is carved to represent a buffalo. At Yambio's funeral there was no great display of grief, and on this being pointed out by a British officer, an Arab-speaking native answered “No ; they are not sorry, for if Yambio had died a natural death and had been buried by his own people, least 300 of them would have been slain at the same time. "After establishing posts throughout the whole district, and explaining the object of the Government, the remainder of the force returned to Waw at the end of March. The expedition was an unqualified success, and reflects great credit on Major Boulnois and all the officers under his command. On the way back one of the officers had rather a narrow escape. A leopard he had wounded badly came straight for him, and though hit again in the neck, was not finished off before it had bitten him deep in the arm and crunched the right hand with its powerful jaws.

div.head: THE "HANDY MAN" IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: A number of naval men are at the present time doing excellent work in the Sudan. Besides a number of Marine Artillery sergeants there are no lets than five officers of the Royal Navy in the service of the Sudan Government. This number is composed of Miralai Bond Bey, Engineer, Commander, R.N., Director of Steamers and Boats ; Kaimakam Fell, Lieutenant, R.N., Bahr-el-Ghazal Special Service : Kaimakam Drury Bey, Lieutenant, R.N., controller Sudan Ports, Suskin , Bimbashi Bayldon, R.N., Bahr-el-Ghazal Special Service ; Bimbashi Scott Hill, R.N., Assistant-Director, Steamers and Boats. The Marine Artillery sergeants include Messrs. Sebright, Evans, Knowles, Sears, Muller, and others, all of whom are doing very good work in the service of the Sudan Government.

div.head: THE UPPER NILE.
div.p: Addressing the Royal Geographical Society on Monday week on “The Nile Province of Western Uganda," Lient.Col C. Delme Radcliffe, M.V.O., said when he took over the civil and military charge of the Nile District from Col. Martyr he found the parapet and ditches of Emin Pasha's old station at Wadelai, on the left bank, in a fair state of preservation, though the buildings had disappeared. The natives remembered Emin well. Of Gordon only a few natives seemed to know anything, though most of those living near the river had heard of “Godun," as he was called, and an interesting relic had been secured in the shape of an Austrian bentwood chair, which Gordon had given to the chief Gimorro. The chair was to be seen in a room adjoining the lecture theatre.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: H.M.’s cruisers “Canopus" and “Goliath” arrived at Suez this morning from Port Said
and are now coaling in the Suez Bay. They will both sail for the China station next Friday to relieve H.M.S. "Ocean" and “Centurion."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Cunard S.S. “Pavia" sailed for Liver-pool yesterday afternoon with a full cargo, including 1,661 bales cotton and 10,664 bags onions.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. “El Kahira” will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port-Said on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrout, Tripoli,’ Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnaos and Limassol.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID. UNSAFE BUILDINGS
div.p: Yesterday, for the second time during the past month, a certain house situated in the Greek quarter, not for from the bazaar, caught fire. The house if built of wood and was much damaged. No lives were lost end the fire was extinguished without the assistance of the Fire Brigade. There are many blocks of this class of wooden building in Port Said, which were constructed soon after the opening of the canal and arc now very unsafe and insanitary.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY '
div.p: In connection with the coming changes in the administration of the Suez Canal Company, -changes rendered necessary by the retirement of M. Tillier,—I understand that Sir H. Austin Lee, K.C.B., etc., the resident British director of the company in Paris, is to come to Egypt in November on a special mission. Mr Hughes, the recently appointed director, and possibly one other British member, on the board, will accompany him. Preparations to receive these gentlemen are being discussed.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: At dawn yesterday H.M.S. "Canopus” arrived from Portsmouth and entered the canal at once, just as H.M.S. “Goliath" arrived in from sea. The latter vessel only remained in the port, two hours and then proceeded. The original idea was that they were both to coal and provision here, but their great draught of water (26’.2”) made that impossible.

div.head: A LUGUBRIOUS FIND.
div.p: On Saturday morning last the body of a newly born male child was discovered behind the offices of the Orient Line. The greater part of the child's abdomen had been apparently devoured by dogs. The police are engaged on an enquiry, with so for no result.

div.head: RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: At Kantars, to-day, a native railway employe, in attempting to board the up train, which was passing at the tune, slipped and fall between the rails, the entire train passing over his body. The tram was sent back to Kantara soon after its arrival here in order that the officials interested could assist at the enquiry, which was held at noon.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING. GOLD AND GEM SYNDICATE
div.p: The secretary writes: — "The company's engineer, Mr. John James,reports that developments on the property are proceeding satisfactorily. Sikait Emerald mines—The new shaft to cut the Emerald measures below water level has been temporarily suspended, owing to the impossibility of obtaining a regular supply of explosives in the country. Hangallya Gold mines— Water has been struck in the new water shaft. The main drive at Wady level is being continued on the lode, which it will be remembered assayed 11 ozs of gold per ton. The tramway is now completed op to the face. New discoveries—Two gold mines have been located, bringing up the total number of gold mines at present discovered to 21. One of these by pan assay gives 1/1/2 oz of gold per ton. It is described by Mr. James as the largest yet discovered, with enormous tailings heaps. Copper— A few miles south-west of Sherm Sheikh harbour Mr. James has located a virgin copper field of great extent, containing immense lodes hitherto unworked by the ancients. Samples of carbonate are taken from the surface have been assayed in London, which give‘14 per cent of copper."

div.head: UM RUS MINE
div.p: The second monthly crushing of the Um Rus Mine is decidedly encouraging. The production was 489oz. of gold, as compared with 351oz. for April, the average yield per ton working out at 20jewt. (including 3dwt. in the stored tailings), as compared with 184dwt. Important also is the striking at the lowest level of a vein 22in. wide, and assaying 33dwt to the ton. There is satisfactory news also from the Atallah Mine of the Central Egypt Exploration Company, and a few more favorable developments will serve to neutralize the North Nile Valley affair. There is room for-much expansion in the Egyptian market, provided the mining industry shows that it is good for something, and the strong hand of the Government is there to prevent gross abuses.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CAB-STANDS.
div.p: "Enquirer” writes:—I wish to understand the meaning of certain excellent arrangements evidently formulated by the officials of the Gouvernorst of Alexandria, but which appear to be words only, as no one needs the instructions. I refer to the "writing on the wall" here and there stating that "there is room here for a stand of 4 cabs and in others for 6, and so on." I have never yet found any cabs taking up their positions on these legalized stands but crawlers are still crawling and others place their carriages and horses half across the end of a street so as to be seen down the whole of it, to the great inconvenience of those turning into these streets when the abuggies are begged to "kasskiss” and get out of the way. In the early morning no cabs are to be found down the whole length of Rosetta-road, which is a long one, and this is a great inconvenience to people who do not keep their own carriages. The same thing occurs late in the evening. If the “writing on the wall" has any in it why are there instructions treated as null and void.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S DANGER,
THE REVOLT IN YEMEN.
div.p: The revolt of Southern Arabia against the Sultan may prove to be an event of much more than local importance. The eastern shores of the Red Sea are to little frequented by Europeans that it is only on rare occasions that any news from the vast tracts of country which were known to the Romans as Arabia Felix reaches the outside world. Running from north to South, the three divisions of territory known as the Hedjaz, the Azir, and the Yemen are nominally provinces of the Turkish Empire, though Turkish rule has never effectively penetrated into the less accessible mountain districts. The Hedjaz is by far the most important of those divisions, for it contains the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, the possession of which is the visible proof to the Mahomedan world of the Sultan’s title to be regarded as Caliph. The Azir is the wildest and the most inhospitable of these regions, and is peopled largely by tribes which adhere to the doctrines of the Shia sect, and consequently repudiate altogether the claim of a Sunnite Sultan to spiritual supremacy. The Shia doctrine is also widely held in the Yemen, which, owing to the fertility of its mountain valleys and the comparative excellence of its climate, is economically a possession of considerable importance. This fertility has attracted settlers from the earliest times, and the Yemen can show traces of a very remarkable civilisation, believed by some to Ira coeval with that of ancient Egypt. The Yemen, from its geographical position, was one of the new forces which were born into the world with Mahomed, and many of the Imams, the semiecclesiastical, semi-civil rulers, who for centuries exercised an uncertain sway over the Arab tribes which peopled it, were of the blood of the Prophet. The Turkish power was first effectually established in the country in the reign of Suleiman tho Magnificent, and by the middle of the sixteenth century all the coast of Arabia acknowledged the Turkish rule, and Sanaa became the seat of the Pasha of Yemen. The Turkish occupation came to an end in 1630, and one Kasim, a descendant of the Prophet, founded a line of Imams which continued in power for more than two centuries, until the lawless state of the country, which rendered caravan trade impossible, induced the Turks to reoccupy the country and restore the direct rule of the Porte in 1872. The Yemen, however, has proved no bed of roses to the Turks during the last thirty years. The prevalence of the Shia doctrine, which makes the rule of a Sunnite Sovereign highly repugnant to the Arab trioesinen, the spirit of independence which characterises mountaineers all the word over, and the incompetence and rapacity of the Turkish officials have all militated against the establishment of a lasting peace. A dangerous revolt broke out in 1892, and the existence of a representative of the ancient Imams, in the shape of Ahmed ed-Din, who, however, does not appear to have been very anxious to play the part of national hero, gave it the character of a religious war. The Porte, by a lavish expenditure of men and money, managed to scotch the rebellion, but the embers of disaffection have continued to smoulder, and at no time has the Yemen been completely free from trouble.

The proximate cause of the present outbreak is not clear, though the German semi-official Press, by the way, has already satisfied itself that it is due to a deep-laid scheme on the part of the British Government to prepare the way for the establishment of British supremacy in the Arabian peninsula. Putting aside this ingenious fabrication, which is probably intended chiefly for consumption in Constantinople, we can entertain no doubt as to the serious proportions to which the rising has attained. News reached this country at the end of February that the whole country south of Sanaa was in a state of insurrection, and that the towns of Kataba and Tais had already fallen into the hands of the insurgents Ominous reports began to arrive of wholesale desertion from the Turkish ranks, and, though the town of Sanaa held out stubbornly for a time, Ali Riza Pasha, who attempted to relieve it with seven battalions of infantry and a battery of artillery, only succeeded in entering the town with the loss of his guns and a large portion of his force. A few days afterwards, on April 30, the town surrendered to the insurgents, whose booty included thirty - guns and 20,000 rifles, with a considerable quantity of ammunition. So far we have beard nothing of any attempt to proclaim an Imam; but, if it is true that Mahmud Yahya, who is described as the principal Sheikh of Yemen, has arrived in Constantinople to submit to the Government certain proposals for the autonomy of the Yemen in return tor the payment of an annual tribute, it is clear that the insurgents will not be content with the mere redress of abuses or the dismissal of unpopular officials.

The Ottoman Government appears to be doing its best to hurry troops and stores down to Hodeida, but the Syrian reinforcements which have already arrived have proved unsatisfactory, and the attempt to mobilise Redif battalions in Albania has been attended with great difficulties. Drafts are also being sent from the Adrianople command, and orders have been given for the calling out of a division of the Angora Re Ids, whose headquarters are in Constantipole. Rita Pasha, who is either killed or a prisoner, has been succeeded in the command by Marshal Ahmed Fevzi Pasha. The secession of the Yemen, if carried out, would be a very serious blow to the Turkish power ; for the ridings of a successful revolt could not fail to spread to the Azir and the Hedjsz, and might raise throughout the Arabian peninsula the racial fanaticism of all the bribes whose traditional hatred of the Turk has never been curbed except by fear. Even in modern times the Wahabi movement has shown how sudden end overwhelming such outbreaks are apt to be amongst the fierce tribesmen of Arabia. Less than a hundred years ago, Mecca and Medina themselves fell into the hands of the Arab Puritans, and were wrested from them only by the military intervention of Egypt under Mohamed Ali. Happily for Egypt, Egyptian troops are no longer at the beck and call of the Sultan. The magnitude of the military preparations ordered by Abdul Hamid gives, however, the measure of the anxiety into which events in the Yemen have plunged tho Imperial mind. A general uprising in Arabia is not, perhaps, a likely contingency, but it does not need any very intimate acquaintance with the workings of the Mahomedan mind to be able to form an estimate of the far reaching effects upon the position of the Sultab as a factor in international politics if he were ultimately to lose his bold over the cradle of Islam. (The Times).

div.head: THE PHYSICAL EFFECTS OF ALCOHOL.
div.p: A largely attended meeting was held in the great hail of the Church House, Loudon, last week by the Women's Union of the Church of England Temperance Society. Canon J. W. Horsley presided. At this mooting an address was given by Sir Frederick Treves on "The physical effects of the use of alcohol," which should prove of much interest in this country, owing to the prominence given to the drink question of late-especially by the remarks made by Lord Cromer. The hands of all temperance reformers ought to be greatly strengthened by such a speech as the following.

Sir Frederick Treves in his address said that alcohol was, of course, distinctly a poison. It had certain uses, like other poisons, but the limitations on its use should be as strict as on argenic, opium, and strychnia. It was a curiously insidious poison, producing effects which seemed to be only relieved by taking more of it a remark which applied to another insidious poison, morphia, or opium. It had a certain position as medicine, but in the last 25 years its use by the medical profession had steadily and emphatically diminished. People were often heard to say that alcohol was an excellent appetiser when taken before meals. But the appetite did not need artificial stimulation; if the body wanted feeding it demanded food. As for its "aiding digestion," it hindered digestion even when taken in small amounts, as could be easily demonstrated. Then there was the idea that alcohol was strengthening. As a fact, it curiously modified the nourishment of the body ; it greatly lessened the output of carbonic acid—a very important matter—so that the drunkard was necessarily aa ill-nourished man ; and to reach the acme of physical condition was impossible if any alcohol was used. Its stimulating effect was only momentary, and after that had passed off the capacity for work fell enormously. Alcohol, as it were, brought up the whole of the reserve forces of the body and threw them into action, and when those were used up there was nothing to fall back on. It dissipated rather than conserved bodily energy. As a work producer it was exceedingly extravagant, and might lead to a physical bankruptcy ; and he was not speaking, he would remind them, excessive drinking. It was a curious fact that troops could not march on alcohol. In the Ladysmith relief column, which he accompanied, the first men to drop out were simply the men who drank. The fact was as clear as if they had all borne labels on their backs. As for the statement that alcohol was "a great thing, for the circulation" it increased the heart-beat and reddened the skin by using up the body’s reserve power, but then the heart’s action became emphatically weaker, a temporary effect being got at an enormous cost. The action of alcohol on the central nervous system was very definite, and was that of a functional poison, first stimulating and then depressing the nervous system. The higher nervous centres went first, becoming slightly dulled. The mar who worked on even a moderate amount of alcohol was not at his best. Fine work could not be done under that condition. The use of alcohol was absolutely inconsistent with a surgeon’s work, or with any work demanding quick and alert judgment. He was much struck by the number of professional men who for this reason had discontinued the use of alcohol in the middle of the day. The last notion he would refer to was that alcohol kept out the cold—that a "little nip” was good when going out into cold air, and so forth. In the words of a great authority, alcohol really lowered the temperature of the body by increased loss of beat and to some extent by increased oxidation, and much reduced the power of the body to resist cold. Finally, he would say that the great and laudable ambition of all, and especially of young men, to be "fit” could not possibly be achieved if they took alcohol. It was simply preposterous to suppose that any young healthy person needed any alcohol whatever; and, indeed, he was much better without even the smallest amount of it. Having spent the greater part of his life operating, he would say, with Six James Paget, that of all people those he dreaded to operate on were the drinkers. He hoped that what he had said would help his bearers to answer such absolute fallacies as "a glass of port can do you no harm."
Mr. W. Joynson-Hicks afterwards spoke on the economic aspects of the temperance question, and Canon Horsley on the spiritual side of the work.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE "ESPLANADE."
div.p: To the editor of the Egyptian Gazette

Dear Sir,—I should be glad to know through the medium of your paper what is the obejection on the part of the Municipality to the forming of a good driving road round the eastern harbour. In civilised countries the roads are made first and then houses. The rule hitherto in Egypt generally has been the contrary. Property at once goes up in value when good roads have been made. The plans for the building allotments, I hear, are all drawn up and to be seen at the Municipality, and I therefore suggest that the esplanade should be taken in hand at once to enable people at any rate to drive round to Ras-el-Tin by an airy and pleasant route instead of through the smelly slum which up to now has been the only way for Ministers attending Councils at the Palace, Consuls paying official calls on board men-of-war, and for all those who attend receptions at Ras-el-Tin (to say nothing of the frequenters of the Yacht Club), to arrive at their destination. In the name of commonsense let us have the enjoyment of this new outlet after all the public money that has been spent on improvements which may be carried out when the mish-mish are ripe, and most of us dead and buried. As I said above in Europe roads come before houses.—Faithfully yours, Common Sense.

div.head: A PUBLIC DANGER.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette: Sir I beg to call your attention to the extreme carelessness of the man employed at the level crossing on the Pyramids road. On several occasions, notwithstanding the new regulating bell, which announces the approach of the train, the gates have barely been closed before the train rushed past To- day (May 20) about 5.30, if it had not been for the intelligence of a small child, who woke the sleeping attendant, the train would have passed the crossing at full speed with all the gates wide open! As it was there was only time to close one pair of gates. It is hardly necessary to point out how serious a danger this is to the public on such a frequented road as that of the Pyramids.

I may also state that the driver of the passenger train failed to sound the whistle, which he should do according to the rules, on nearing a level crossing. I enclose my card, and remain, Sir, etc., Pro Bono Publico. Cairo, May 20.

Le départ de M. Rémy a été l'occasion de nombreux témoignages de sympathie de la part non seulement de la oolonie belge, nais encore 'des colonies étrangères. Tous ceux qui ont eu avoc lui des relations d’affaires ou ont du l’aborder en sa qualité de oonsul ont gardé do son affabilité le meilleur souvenir. Alexandrin do longue date, M. Rémy s’est acquis en •Egypte un renom universel pour la correction de sa oonduitc et l’intégrité de son caractère. Au point de vue matériel sa situation est loin d’être aussi brillante, et o’est pourquoi le voilà contraint, aprèa36 ans do séjour à Alexandrie, à aller travailles en Belgique.

On a parlé-d’une prétendue fortune, mais peut-on donner ce nom à des actions do la Boulangerie Mécanique et à quelques Indus- trielles 1 Ceux qui font à ce sujet des allusions malveillantes se montreraient plus réservés si la fortune dont ils parlent existait réelle- ment. Noue en avons pour prouve mille exemples sous les yeux. Quant à la déooofi- ture de l’industrielle et de la Boulangerie Mécanique dont les mêmes personnes sem- blent vouloir lui taire un oritne, nul moins quo loi n’y a oontpbué et il est un des rares pro- motoursde l’industrielle qui n'ait point profité dans l’affaire Philippart

Ses ennemis affirment enoore qu’il a reçu l’ordre de démissionner et que o’est là l'unique raison de son départ Rien n’est plus faux. Il y avait fort longtemps déjà que M. Rémy dé li- rait se retirer. Lors du 35e anniversaire de son séjour, en janvier 19W, il annonça qu’il était définitivement résolu à quitter le pays. Ce n’est done pas là un décision subite, prove nant d’on ordre, mais une résolution de longuo date et absolument personnelle.

En réponse aux accusationi formulé» contre lui. alors qu'il n’est plus là pour se défendre, ( nou* adressons à ce vieil égyptien ne salut oôrdiat. Sou seul tort est de n'avoir pas su s’enrichir, comme tant d’autres.
Un Bkloe. Alexandrie, le 24 mai 1905.

div.head: THE HASHISH TRAFFIC.
THE EGYPTO-HELLENIC CONVENTION
div.p: The negotiations in regard to the terms of the new commercial convention between Egypt and Greece have not yet armed at any definite hasis. The Egyptian Government insists on the prohibition of hashish cultivation in Greece, but the Hellenic Government demurs to this concession, as the cultivation of hashish is one of the thief resources of the central plateau of the Peloponnesus. The attitude of the Egyptian Government in this matter is alluded to in the following terms in Lord Cromer's Report:-

In the course of last year, the Egyptian Government denounced tho Commercial Convention with Greece. The terms of a new Convention are now under discussion. It is of great importance in Egyptian interests that the importation of hashish should be stopped, and also that greater facilities should be accorded to the police to deal with smugglers and keepers of disorderly houses, of whom a large number are Greek subjects.
The "Messager d'Athenes" remarks as follows:-

(XXXXX) parait que le gouvernement bellenique pourrait tout au plus prendre l'engagement de restreindre la culture de cette plante que l'on introduit en contrebande en pays musulmans et surtout en Egypte.

C'est une question d'hygiine ponree dernier pays! 11 en sera blentOt do memo ches uoua Le noiubre des In incurs de habhiche augments d'annde en ounce dans les. bassos classw d’Atbiues et do Price, ot 1'on aait les funestes diet., du chnuvre indieu sur l orgauisme.”

The spread of hashish smoking among the inhabitants of Athens and the Piraeus must sooner or later force the Hellenic Government in the interests of its own people to come round to the standpoint of the Egyptian Government. In regard to the baneful effects of the drug, it is worth noting that the number of persons, whose insanity is due to the use of hashish, admitted to the lunatic asylum at Abbassieh, has been steadily decreasing ol late years. In 1897, these constituded 33 per cent. Of the total number of male patients. In 1904, out of 350 male patients, only 53, or about 15 per cent, were insane owing to the use of hashish. But these figures cannot be considered as conclusive evidence that the use of hashish is decreasing. The diminution may tie, and perhaps is, due to the fact that, by reason of the very limited accommodation available at the asylum, instructions have been issued to the local doctors only to send the worst cases to Abbassieh. Thus, out of 208 cases of insanity from all causes, admitted into the Alexandria Hospital during the past year, only 37 were sent to Abbassieh. The campaign against the use of the drug continues, but, except in, so far as its result is to raise the price, which is now as high as 50 fr. a kilog., it cannot be said to be very successful. There is a considerable demand for the drug. The individual consumer is not very greatly affected by the rise in price. A large number of low class Europeans and Egyptians find the wholesale and retail trade very lucrative. The Coastguard, Customs, and Police seized 21,369 kilog. of hashish in the course of last year. This was about 3,000 kilog. less than in 1903. The diminution is mainly due to the fact that formerly the greater portion of the hashish brought into Egypt came from Tripoli along the coast to Alexandria. It is now landed in Tripoli, thence carried south to the Oasis of Baharieh siid Dakhleh, and so into Egypt. The change of route enhances the difficulty of capture. The case is, in many respects, the same as that of the Slave Trade. So long as the demand and the supply exist, it is almost impossible to prevent evasions of the law; no sooner is one route closed to the smuggler, than another is opened up. The difficulties of the Coastguard and the Customs with regard to the smugglers, and those of the police with regard to retailers and consumers, are obvious. It is difficult to do very much more than we already do in Egypt What is wanted is that Greece should prohibit die cultivation of hashish. In this, as in some other instances, the regime of the Capitulations tends to the demoralisation of the country. At the same time, a'recent change in the law, under which tenants of cafes, &c, sentenced to be permanently closed, can no longer frustrate the ends of justice by putting forward others as nominal holders, has somewhat strengthened the hands of the police.

div.head: A STATUETTE OF ISIS.
div.p: For the purpose of its being included in the Corpus of Semitic Inscriptions, M. Gaston Maspero forwarded to Paris a photograph of a statuette of Isis having a Phoenician inscription. The figure is of the ordinary Egyptian type of the goddess, with the infant Horus upon her lap, and it may be seen by visitors to the Cairo Museum. The Phoenician text, as read by M. Clermont Gannesu, is as follows "Gertsaphon son of 'Azer, son of Chalcat...to his mistress Achtoret” The text proves that the donor of the statuette identified Isis with the Syrian Achtoret, whom we know, on the other side, was closely connected with the Bsbylonian Ishtar. The style of the statuette and paleographical character of the inscription indicate early in the 4th century B.C. as the date of its manufacture.

div.head: TRADE CRISIS IN EGYPT.
OFFICIALS' INDEBTEDNESS.
div.p: A correspondent writes —Although repeated references to the present trade crisis have not, so far as I know, led to a formal Government enquiry, they appear to have caused, many independent enquiries to be made, and from a number of communications received I gather that the present “trade financial crisis" is to a great extent caused by the evil efforts or traders of a Khedivial decree promulgated during the last Ministry of Riaz Pasha, with the approval of Lord Cromer, depriving creditors of the right established by the laws of the country (and very freely used up till then) to lay or levy claims for debts against the salary of any employe of the Egyptian Government.

When this decree became law the indebtedness to local tradespeople of Government employes was very considerable, and it kept on increasing, until it now amoun's to a sum estimated at over a million sterling. The trader, on the one hand, being able to take any step with a view to its recovery, the Government employs, on the other, feels perfectly secure from oven the risk of his indebtedness becoming known to his chief. It is from the date of this decree that traders have found it necessary to demand the long credits for which Egypt has now become famous in the manufacturing centres of Europe.

It causes no little surprise in commercial circles that Lord Cromer should hare given his approval to such a law—knowing as he must how it was likely to be abused in a country like this—more especially at the present moment, when he recommends a revision of the Capitulations, while he keeps in force a decree which, to say the least of it, affords undue protection to the Government employe, as it protects him from the usual liability to be called upon to pay his just debts, etc. For full evidence of its evil effects on traders we have only to refer to the official daily records of the Mixed Tribunals, where failures are the order of the day.

div.head: THE MAID OF HONOR
A PLEASANT GLIMPSE OF QUEEN ALEXANDRA.
div.p: The Court lady of old days, says Lady Violet Greville, in the "New York Tribune," was merely a superior kind of servant ; the Maid of Honor of to-day is a charming, accomplished girl whose duty is to make herself pleasant to the guests and talk agreeably to the important personages who may be visiting at the castle. She should be a good linguist, have read the most talked-of books of the day, and possess musical tastes. She is expected to take a hand at bridge, if required to make up a rubber ; but she must not play for money, as the Queen disapproves of girls gambling or playing for larger stakes than they can well afford. Smoking cigarettes, too, which is such a modern craze, is discountenanced by the Queen.

The life of a Maid of Honor is an interesting one: she is brought in contact with all sorts of illustrious people ; she constahtly meets celebrities; she hears talk on all kinds of subjects ; she receives in fact a most cosmopolitan education—the education that makes a wise woman of the world. She learns tact, sense, courtesy, and becomes infinitely adaptable. Court life being so much simpler than in the past, it also has become more human and more real. Much precious time no longer is wasted in idle etiquette or the trivial gossip and petty jangling and scandal mongering of a superior housekeeper’s room, of which we get such vivid glimpses in the d’Arblay Memoirs.

A delightful story is told of Queen Alexandra, which exhibits the pleasant relations existing between her and her Maids of Honor. On one occasion one of the young women arrived at the castle minus her luggage, and quietly informed her Majesty of the fact. The Queen, instead of reproving her for carelessness, merely remarked : “My dear child, how did you manage it? I never lose mine."

div.head: AUSTRIA AND MONTENEGRO.
div.p: It is significant of the armed neutrality which has existed between Montenegro and Austria- Hungary since the occupation of Bosnia and Herzegovina by the latter after the Berlin Congress, that no treaty of commerce has ever been drawn up between the two countries. This is owing to no backwardness on the part of Montenegro, for as soon as his State was actually independent of Turkish control Prince Nicolas made a point of entering into treaties with the Powers of Europe, and that between Great Britain and Montenegro was drawn up as far back as 1881. At present, Mr. Moisanovich, the Montenegrin Minister of Finance, is in Vienna, negotiating with Herr Call, the Austrian Minister of Commerce, on the subject of the conclusion of a treaty. The want of a commercial convention is very prejudicial to the little mountain principality, as its goods are very heavily taxed by the Austro-Hungarian Custom House. But, on the other hand, the present position of affairs gives rise to an immense amount of smuggling across the frontier, with the result that “untoward incidents" are always owning between the smugglers and the Austrian Custom House guards. The frontier is an extremely difficult one to watch, and the Montenegrins are always ready for a fight. The consequence is that however friendly Vienna and Cettigne may be, relations on the border are very strained. But a commercial treaty will do away with the tension which at present exists.

div.head: NEW HOSPITAL TO BE BUILT.
SITE AT HADRA SELECTED.
div.p: In view of the present movement in favor of the establishment of a British cottage hospital or nursing home at Alexandria, special interest is attached to the report on the work of the Deaconesses’ Hospital in our city for the year 1904, which has just been issued. The committee, in their report, state that last year they were preoccupied with the question of removing the hospital to another site. The necessity for this imposed itself on them owing to the fact that the lands contiguous to the hospital are now covered with houses inhabited by a very dense population. Again, the removal of the isolation ward for contagious diseases had become an urgent matter. It not haying been found suitable to build on the only piece of vacant ground in the immediate vicinity, the committee decided to dispose of the present site and acquire another, of a more suitable character. They selected a large piece of ground at Hadra, opposite the new prison, and favorable terms having been obtained from the Government, the purchase was concluded. As soon as a satisfactory offer can be obtained for the actual site of the hospital, the construction of the new building will be begun. In the meantime, several improvements and additions have been made to the present premises to meet urgent requirements. It is very regrettable, however, say the committee, that in making the now operating-theatres, the major portion of the rooms formerly need as a polyclinique had to be taken, and the latter was consequently closed. Statistics showed that 9,627 patients only were treated in the polyclinique in 1904, as against 24,562 in 1903. To allow of this work—which is of great benefit, especially to the native population-being carried on, therefore, a kiosk was erected in the north-east corner of the garden. For some time past, the report continues, the necessity has been felt of cresting another isolation ward for serious contagious maladies, such as smallpox, etc., and it was decided to establish this ward as conveniently as possible.

Coming to the statistical portion of the report, we find that during last year, 1,606 patients (including 91 remaining over from the previous year) were treated in the hospital. This was the largest number on record, the next highest figure being reached in 1903, when 1,624 patients received treatment. Of the total last year, 1,177 were men (170 of them Bailors), 346 women, and 83 children. 1,191 left the hospital cured, 178 got better, 70 were discharged as incurable, and 73 died, leaving 94 under treatment at December 31. Classed according to their religious beliefs, 266 were Protestants, 264 Roman Catholics, 3 Greek Catholics, 79 Greek Orthodox, 51 Copts, 63 Armenian Orthodox, 17 Maronites, 36 Jews, 836 Moslems, and 1 Theosophite. These represented no less than 21 different nationalities. Among Europeans, the British predominated, there having been 195 British subjects in hospital during the year (128 are classed as “English" and 72 from British possessions). The next largest number of Europeans treated were Germans, viz., 115. Of Americans there were 12. On an average, 94 beds were oocupied per day during the year. 45 patients occupied first-class rooms, 270 were in the second-class, and 1,291 in the wards. Only three Englishmen were treated gratuitously during the year, while 49 Germans received free treatment.

The receipts of the hospital during 1904 amounted to P.T. 120,429 and the expendi- ture P.T. 339,671. The rooeipts included a subvention from the British Government (for 1903) of P.T. 4,875, from the German Government of P.T. 2,925, from the Swiss Government of P.T. 775, and from the Alexandria Municipality of P.T. 5,000. The subscriptions amounted to £194. A large number of gifts were received during the year, including one of a complete Routgen Ray apparatus from Mrs. Bindernagel.

div.head: CROPS AND WEATHER
div.p: Cyprus, May 16.

Reports from various parts of the Island show that considerable damage was done to crops by the severe hailstorms at the end of April. The barley suffered perhaps the most, but oats, vines, potatoes, and certain fruit trees were also injured to some extent. The weather for the last week has been hot, though not unpleasantly so.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The Legislative Council reassembled on the 17th instant, having adjourned on 20th ult.

div.head: SUMMER RESORT FOR EGYPTIANS.
div.p: It is believed that several Anglo Egyptum officials and their familiar contemplate visiting Mt. Troodos during the summer-season. It is certainly a delightful and most healthy place during the hot months. It is, however, very necessary that intending visitors should make their arrangements beforehand as to camping, as the accommodation is very limited and the only “huts", are allotted to Cyprus Government officials. A small hotel was opened last year by Mr. Selim Houry, of Limassol, and I believe that one is to be started this year by Mr. Majous Houry, of Limassol. There has been a rather larger number of visitors to the Island than usual during the winter, and several intend remaining until the autumn.

div.head: RAILWAY DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: Col. the Hon. M. G. Talbot, R.E., and his brother arrived on a visit from Egypt last month, and on the 27th April Mr. Shelford, the Consulting Engineer for the Cyprus Railway, came to inspect the work so far completed. The construction of the railway proceeds steadily, the railhead being now within a few miles of Angastina, a distance of about 22 miles from the terminus.

div.head: REAPING MACHINES.
div.p: There has been a greater demand than usual for reaping machines this season, and it is hoped that the native agriculturists are now coming to recognise their utility.

div.head: EGYPT AND CYPRUS MAIL
div.p: The existing mail contract with Bell’s Steamship Line terminates in June next, and much interest is felt in regard to the new arrangements that may be made for carrying the mail between Egypt and Cyprus.

div.head: EGYPTIAN JOURNALISM.
JEROME HART IN THE SAN FRANCISCO "ARGONAUT"
div.p: The newspapers of Egypt are not very daring sheets. Possibly their birth and growth may have something to do with this timidity. Most American newspapers, like Topsy, "jest growed" ; the Egyptian newspapers seem to have been born "brought up by hand.." This winter, the death of Haikalis Pasha, founder of Le Share d' Alexandrie, brought forth is all the papers some columns of reminiscences concerning the deceased editor—all of most kindly nature. They all agreed on one point—that Haikalis Pasha had founded his paper simply and solely because Khedive Ismail paid him for that purpose an annual subsidy of £7,000. There was no savor of satire in the comment— it had perhaps a slight tinge of envy—that was all. It was unite evident that in the opinion of the scribes of Egypt the jingling of the guineas healed the hurt honor of Haikalis Pasha. This subsidy he received for many years. But when the influence of the deposed khedive ceased to have weight Haikalis Pasha was told that he would have to run his paper without a subsidy. Confronted with this dreadful lot—menaced with the terrible task of meeting his expenditures with his receipts— what did Haikalis Pasha do?
He ran his paper straight

Probably this was the first time it was ever attempted in Egypt. The other papers looked on with awe and admiration. All of the editorial fraternity expressed the highest admiration for his nerve and pluck. One paper said he "lost-several thousand pounds the first year." In fact, all spoke of Haikalis Pasha’s continuing to' run an old-established paper after the cessation of the subsidy in the same tone of admiring deprecation that we in America would adopt in speaking of the demeuted editor; who would attempt to run a religious and temperance daily in any large American city.

With these traditions clinging to the Egyptian press, if is easy to understand that the Egyptian editors speak rather guardedly, not only of persons in power, but of the great hotel-keepers and of the rich shop-keepers. Their caution is so extreme, however, that at times it becomes very droll. As I have said, they are cautious even in talking about the weather, that not committal topic so dear to us all ; for in Egypt it is possible for a newspaper to injure itself with the great hotel- keepers and the rich shop-keepers by talking too freely about the weather when it is bad. In Egypt the weather during the past winter has been by no means all that tho tourists' fairly painted it.

It is not only concerning subsidies that the Egyptian newspapers, from the American newspaper point of view, seem rather odd. I am speaking only of those printed in English and French; there are many journals printed in Arabic, but I know nothing of them. The newspapers published in European languages are mainly remarkable for excluding anything that could offend anybody. Not only do they taboo the weather, but other topics as well. As they depend largely for their income on the advertisements of a limited number of large hotel companies and business houses, they naturally find it difficult to print any unpleasant news concerning them. Therefore they adopt the simple expedient of printing disagreeable personal news in a cryptic fashion without any names. Here is a sample item :

Melancholy Death—Yesterday afternoon a clerk who is very well known, and in the employ, of a prominent merchant, committed suicide in the merchant's office by blowing out his brains with a revolver. His face was much disfigured.

Reserve over the peccadilloes of those in high station is, of course, not followed by tho papers in discussing the misdoings of the lowly. But the editorial habit is hard to lay aside and the crim. con. cases of the populace are told with a brevity which is startling. The following paragraphs (grouped under "Tantah Notes") from a Cairo paper are certainly remarkable:
"Tantah Notes—At Tantah yesterday, George Kantikopoulos returned home unexpectedly to his wife and her paramour, and chopped both their heads off with an axe.
"The Tantah authorities are enforcing the code of contraventions against natives who defile the streets."
“After next Wednesday at Tantah ownerless dogs will be shot by the police."
The same brevity is extended to items not in the line of conjugal revenge, such as the following:
Murder and Robbery- Madame Galli and Madame Benetti were murdered by five ruffians the night before last at Zagazig. The object was plunder. The murderers were arrested.
Here is an excellent four-column story for on American daily told in four lines :

Girl's Body Found-Yesterday the body of a young native girl, daughter of Hassan Ali, was found floating in the Mahmoudieh Canal. Her parents say it was not suicide, as her rings had been torn from her ears.
The arrival of the famous squadron that went around the seas ""'seein' things" was thus briefly chronicled:
Russian Fleet- The division of the Baltic fleet: commanded by Admiral Botrovsky arrived at Port Said yesterday afternoon at two-thirty, and leaves this morning.
A fire in the largest mercantile house in Egypt is thus set down:
Big Fire — The enormous Walker-Meimarachi stores were destroyed by fire yesterday. Two firemen were killed and many injured. Loss £50,000.

Imagine an American daily devoting a few lines only to a fatal fire involving the loss of a quarter of a million. Really, Egypt is not the place for-a hustling American city editor to visit. To read such items as these and to think of the columns of "stories" and the acres of pictures they would make in America would drive such an editor into a highly nervous condition.
But lot us present a few more of those startling items told in this matter-of-fact way :

The Mecca Pilgrims—Over three thousand persons have arrived since Wednesday from Algiers, Morocco, and Stamboul, en route to Mecca. Near Djeddah the last lot of pilgrims found a formidable force of Bedouins awaiting them for plundor. After the fight the pilgrims withdrew, leaving fifty-two of their number dead on the field.
This mild paragraph is calculated to give travellers pause.

Annoyances of Tourists.—A party of twenty tourists went to Sakkara on Monday. The guardian of the rains refused to recognise their tickets of admission. A heated debate followed, which was adjourned to Marietta's house. No satisfaction followed. On emerging the tourists found a-horde of threatening Arabs waiting. Their donkey and camel drivers remained neutral, and the tourists fled amid a shower of stones. Some were seriously injured. The tourists were much annoyed.
Here is another ill-mated husband who settles disputes with murder:

Killed His Wife—A public scrivener, a native, living at Gabbari, had a conjugal discussion with his wife which ended by his striking her over the head with an iron bar, killing her instantly. He fled and has not been arrested.
The incidental way in which the robbery of $ 40,000 is just alluded to at the end of this paragraph is altogether delicious :
‘The Mahmal (Holy Carpet) sailed from Suez this afternoon for Jeddah on its way to Mecca.
"A theft of £8,000 took place from the Mahmal train at Abassieh. All search for the culprits lias proved 'fruitless.'"
By committing suicide this young gentleman may have saved himself from committing uxoricide :
Suicide—A young native gentleman of Cairo committed suicide yesterday in order to avoid contracting a marriage which his family were bent upon.
This paragraph is not without singular phases :

Tailors Attack Cafe—Yesterday three British tailors; refused to pay their bill for wine and beer at the Cafe du Phare, Alexandria. When Cesare Giolotti, the cafe-keeper, attempted to force them they assaulted him, and his Arab waiters, beat them severely, smashed chairs and tables, and wrecked the cafe. They then fled, pursued by the police, but reached the quay, and before they could be arrested the three tailors reached their ship, which was just leaving.

I had never associated such wild and reckless brawling with the manners of the gentlemen who wield the shears and goose. Therefore it was with a distinct shock that I read of some tailors—even British tailors —cleaning out a cafe and beating the waiters. I could readily understand it if done by British lords or British navvies. But British tailors! —it seemed incredible. Only the close of the item made me comprehend it—the tailors were sailors.
During the winter just past items like this were by no means rare in the Cairo papers:

Burned to Death—Yesterday a native, Hassan Yussuf was warming himself at a small fire he had made in the street, when his clothing caught fire, and, despite his frantic screams, he was burned to death.

That it should be so cold in Cairo as to cause the natives to make fires in the street may surprise many. It is a very common belief that the Egyptian winter is always hot. True, it is often hot during the winter in Lower Egypt, but it is also frequently cold, and sometimes bitterly cold. The wise traveller takes with him at all times and everywhere, in summer and in winter, both light and heavy clothing. He will find use for both during the Egyptian winter.

The first time I visited. Egypt I shared the common delusion concerning the Egyptian- winter climate; when we went ashore at Alexandria I put on the thinnest garments I had, and took with me a palm-loaf fan and a Panama straw hat. At the last moment some faint gleam of lucidity pierced my darkened brain, and I took with me a railway rag. This, however, was scarcely reasoning—it was probably automatic : "Rail-rug ; rug-rail ; going rail—take rug." It was fortunate for me that I did so, for I verily believe that without it I would have frozen to death between Alexandria and Cairo. Lest that be considered exaggeration, let me add that this winter a train broke down between Alexandria and Cairo ; that no relief train was sent out; that the passengers speedily hired all the spare blankets in the sleeping-car; that the price rose from ten piastres to one hundred piastres per blanket; and that when morning brought a train along two or three of the richest men were wrapped in all of the blankets, and the remainder of the passengers had to be thawed out by exhaust steam from the engine. Seriously, the poor wretches when found were stiff with cold and many of them were made seriously ill.
