div.head: THE CHEMIST IN CAIRO.
BY HORACE WYNDHAM.
div.p: The Arabic word for chemist is "hakim," although it is more generally applied to a doctor. The vocation is in Egypt one of considerable antiquity. It dates, indeed, from Biblical times, as is proved by hieroglyphics that have been discovered showing the practitioners at work. Those early chemists, however, were very much what we should nowadays term herbalists, and combined doctoring with drag dealing. Every tribe had its own "hakim," the calling being handed down from father to son, much as is the case in India to the present day. The methods employed by their descendants remain almost identical with those first adopted, and as a natural consequence, they are scarcely up to date. Among the European chemists, however, doing business in such large centres as Cairo, Alexandria; Port Said, Suez, etc., there is not much to complain of on this account, for the great majority of the practitioners at these places are fully qualified men. Many of them hold London diplomas, while others havo French, German, or Italian ones. The native houses, too, are (with certain exceptions) well conducted.

The European chemists in Cairo are of all nationalities, English, French, German, and Italian predominating. There are also a few Levantines chiefly Turks and Greeks - engaged in the business. These latter, however, minister for the most part to the requirements of the native population, and have their premines in the Muski (or Arab) quarter. This is an overcrowded and evil-smelling district in the eastern part of the town. It is a good trade centre, however, as, on account of the numerous mosques, bazaars, and curiosity shops contained within its boundaries, it is much resorted to by sight-seeing tourists.

With regard to the best class of chemists’ establishments—i.e., those kept by Europeans —nearly all are to be found in the vicinity of the Esbekieh Gardens. They are situated either in the Sharia Kamel Pasha, or the Place de l'Opera-- the chief commercial quarters of Cairo. The principal among them are the New English Dispensary, the Anglo-American Pharmacy, and the London Pharmacy. In the pages of the plain spoken "Boedeker" attention is drawn to the high charges that most of them impose. This complaint is a well-founded one, for the scale is in many cases quite excessive. With regard to proprietary articles this is especially marked. A shilling, for example, is quite a common price to demand for a sixpenny cake of Pears' soap ; while pills and tooth powders are all sold at something like 90 per cent above their face values. There is no real reason for this, as the import duties are quite trifling. A little healthy competition is badly wanted. It would also be good for trade generally, since the host of invalids who flock into Egypt every winter are in the habit of bringing supplies of medicine with them. If they could depend on obtaining what they required at a moderate cost, however, they would undoubtedly patronise the local firms to a greater extent than they seem inclined to do at present.

A good many of the Chemists in Cairo do a brisk business in the sale of photographic goods and the preparation of amateurs' negatives. Every tourist includes, as a matter of course, a camera among his equipment, and is not happy until he has snap-shotted the Pyramids and the Sphinx. These works of art then have to be developed, and the chemist who is not above doing such work finds it highly remunerative. As the customary charge is something like a shilling per film this is not to be wondered at. Another source of profit is derived from the sale of cameras and accessories. Here, again, rates rule very high. The theory that these goods are sold at the same price all over the world does not apply to Egypt.

As in many places abroad, dentistry is often combined with drug selling in Cairo ; at any rate, among the natives. "First-class toothpulling," indeed, is quite a common inscription to find in the shop windows of the Egyptian chemists. Others add dispensing, and also do a little in the way of giving medical advice. Their customers, however, are for the most part drawn from among the Arab residents, as the average European wisely prefers to consult a properly qualified doctor when he is ill. The European chemists do very little advertising, beyond sending out circular letters and price-lists at regular intervals to everyone included in the official directory, and also to the different hotel-managers. The greater part of their business comes to them direct from the local doctors. Of those there are a good number in Cairo and the vicinity, for the host of invalids who winter in the Egyptian capital give the medical fraternity plenty of employment. The chief demand is for tonics and drags calculated to build up the system, while pyretic saline and disinfectant powders are also asked for during the hot weather. There is not much sale for cough-mixtures, as the usual prescription in cases of pulmonary affections is the simple one of open air. If only the Cairo chemist could bottle this up and sell it by the ounce he would speedily realise a fortune!

A line in which a good deal of remunerative business is done by the European firms is that of toilet preparations and j-perfumery. There is always a large and steady demand for these, as lady-visitors find that the strong sun even in December and January, plays havoc with their complexions. On the occasion of a ball at the British Agency, or a big reception at the Khedivial Palace, a tremendous demand arises for pearl powder. In connection with this it is reported that on one occasion, when an important social function was about to take place, a certain astute house created a "corner in this commodity, with the result that it went up to famine price. In vain were heartrending appeals made for even the smallest supply at the old rate; the holder of the stock was deaf to both entreaty and reproach alike. He did not do himself much good, however, by his perverseness, for a rival firm telephoned to Alexandria in time to get enough to satisfy the market. What threatened to develop into a serious crisis was thus happily averted.

Another profitable line is that of supplying medicine chests for shooting-parties who intend visiting the interior, or for tourists contemplating a voyage in a Nile boat. As expeditions of this sort mean travelling to places remote from chemists’ establishment, the possession of a stock of drugs beforehand is necessary. The most popular are those put up in tabloid form, and the experienced tourist never dreams of being unprovided with a selection of these. With the aid of a simple draught (taken at the right time) an attack of fever which might become serious if neglected can frequently be checked. To have recourse to the "remedies" famished (at exorbitant rates) by the local dragomans (guides) is simply suicidal.

The various hospitals in Cairo and the neighbourhood also prove remunerative customers of the leading chemists. During the course of the year three institutions get through a large quantity of drags, as well as surgical appliances. Some of the hospitals are for natives. There is also a big school of medicine in the town where students are trained. This establishment is situated close to a mosque that is famous all over the country as the place in which the "howling Derwishes" go through their weird performances.

The Oriental’s innate love of haggling is, perhaps, nowhere more marked than in the shop of a native chemist. It is impossible, indeed, at these places to buy even a piece of sticking-plaster without first entering upon a vast amount of discussion with regard to the price. To the question “Kam?" ("How much?") a figure out of all proportion to the one that will eventually be accepted is demanded. Thereupon the would-be purchaser shrugs his shoulders and prepares to depart. Before he reaches the door, however, he is lured back by the promise to reduce the charge by the fraction of a farthing. An amount of bargaining then ensues that would make an Englishman think that the purchase of the entire shop was being discussed. In the end the proprietor—calling on Allah and the Beard of the Prophet to witness that he is robbing his wife and family—names a sum that is paid with many protests by the customer. Even then, however, the question of “backsheeh" has to be settled. This is usually not by paying for a cup of coffee. With its consumption peace and goodwill are once more restored.

In their anxiety to secure British patrons some of the native chemists avail themselves of the services of touts. Those men (low class Arabs for the most part) haunt the vicinity of the big hotels resorted to by tourists, and poster the travellers with offers of guidance to the establishments of their employers. At times they scarcely hesitate to drag them off by main force, while at others, on pretence of conducting them to a mosque, they lead them in triumph to the drug shop which they represent. If no purchase is effected here they become abusive. The mention of the word policeman, however, speedily reduces them to politeness again, for the average native has a wholesome respect for the Cairo police. Of course, the best class of native chemists do not descend to these manceuvres at all, while the European ones conduct their businesses with proper regard for dignity. They reap the reward of this, first, in the building up of a remunerative trade, and, secondly, in the establishing of pleasant relations between themselves and their customers.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Two vacancies exist in the Sudan Medical Department for two qualified Doctors of Egyptian or Syrian nationality (Mohammedan, preffered).

Salary for the first two years L.E. 240 year with an increase of L.E. 24 after two years satisfactory service. And subsequent periodical increases according to the Regulations in force at the time being.
After one year's satisfactory probation anitable> candidates will be given the option of being placed the permanent list and coming under the Government Pension scheme.
The probationary year will count towards service for Pension.
Candidates should be unmarried, healthy, and under 36 years of age.

The appointment is subject to the general Government Regulations in force at the time being as regards leave travelling allowance and matters of discipline ; two months' leave is given every year as far as possible.

Testimonials (not more than three)- one, if possible from an English official— may be sent to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum, not later than 31st May 1905 with a letter of application in the candidate's own handwriting, stating his qualification and his appointments since becoming qualified.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
